ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Linear algebra, matrices, vectors, least squares.
I learned what matrices are as well as the basic computational applications of linear algebra.
We learned the most significant linear algebra theorems and operations, applied to modern-day use cases, including how linear algebra proves useful to important engineering software like MATLAB.
Learned the basics behind linear algebra and how to solve problems relating to linear algebra.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really liked that we had to do a project, I think that is probably my only take away from this class. The build-up of this class is not very clear, sometimes I couldn't understand how things connected or why are we learning about them
Psets are pretty short and a good representation of what the exams will be. I thought it was a really manageable, fair amount of work.
The final project was poorly organized and graded too generously.
Hanwhen was incredible. However it was hard to get replies via email from James

The pacing of this course felt slightly uneven. Many lectures on the basics of vector-matrix and matrix-matrix multiplication could be condensed to leave more time for the more abstract/ conceptually challenging chapters on eigenvalues/vectors and spaces. The current distribution makes the course feel end-heavy, with the core concepts of subspaces and spanning covered at unnecessary speed.

Overall, this is a great course. I liked the project in lieu of a second midterm. I wish Canvas quizzes were assigned ahead of lectures (in addition to psets) to introduce topics and check understanding.

A huge weakness is that this course is too math-oriented and not applications-based. One way that the course could be improved is by focusing on least squares and other applications like finite element analysis. I understand that the course is for all backgrounds but perhaps there can be a push for a course in linear algebra that is exclusively for stats majors or for engineering majors.
The problem sets followed along the recommended textbook which was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend if you have to take it for your major. It was not an interesting class, and I could only sit through them because I knew it might be helpful for my major. If you are a mathy person, you might find this class easy.

Sure, if you like math. I would definitely take it over 225 (unless you are a literal pure math major); it's so much easier and you actually end up learning more linear algebra concepts cause you don't have to spend all semester proving the existence of the cartesian plane. I honestly really liked this class and thought the workload was super manageable. Really wasn't too hard. I liked it much much better than 120.
Yes, everyone interested in pursuing either engineering or statistics and data science will find this course very useful.
Only take this if you need it as a prerequisite. This course is not really helpful and the material covered can be compressed easily into 5 weeks.
